A week after this was declared over, DRC were confronted with aÂ 10th outbreak in North Kivu Province. On 1 August 2018, the Ministry of Health of the Democratic Republic of the Congo notified WHO of a new outbreak of Ebola virus disease (EVD) in North Kivu Province, in the eastern part of the country. The province of North Kivu is among the most populated provinces, with eight million inhabitants. It shares borders with four other provinces (Ituri, South Kivu, Maniema and Tshopo) as well as with Uganda and Rwanda. (There is a tangible risk of EVD transmission in Uganda and Rwanda).Â The sub-region has been experiencing intense insecurity and worsening humanitarian crisis, with over one million internally displaced people and a continuous efflux of refugees to the neighbouring countries, including Uganda, Burundi and Tanzania. The protracted conflict context makes the emergency response activities more difficult because of restrained access and security risks. The EVD outbreak is rapidly evolving, with more new confirmed cases and deaths occurring. WHO regional risk raised to HIGH.
